might be useful to prefix this with "[the]"

timeline.author: APickledWalrus

timeline.bodyText: You should check if the condition is negated here, so if it is negated, you can return "server is not whitelisted"
timeline.author: APickledWalrus

timeline.bodyText: What happens if you call this method and there are no whitelisted players? Does it return an empty list or null?
timeline.author: APickledWalrus

timeline.bodyText: IMO you should use curly brackets when you have an it / else if / else, but I’m not sure what the conventions say about that actually
timeline.author: APickledWalrus

replies.bodyText: I checked and doing that is fine
replies.author: DeltaRays

timeline.bodyText: This isn’t proper usage of REMOVE_ALL, since really your just clearing it, not removing a specific type from the list
timeline.author: APickledWalrus

replies.bodyText: Well removing all players from the list = resetting it
replies.author: DeltaRays

replies.bodyText:
Yes, but you’re not always removing players. REMOVE_ALL is used like:
remove all <something> from <something>
remove all creepers from the whitelist doesn’t really make sense.
replies.author: APickledWalrus

replies.bodyText: For the record, REMOVE_ALL has a somewhat specific usage and it is being able to remove all duplicates of a list, considering REMOVE just removes the first one that it encounters. You can't have duplicates in a whitelist so it's rather useless here.
replies.author: FranKusmiruk

timeline.bodyText: I recommend splitting this up over several lines (to avoid having one long line)
timeline.author: APickledWalrus
APickledWalrus

replies.bodyText: I would make this change to avoid repetitive code.
